ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed a more comprehensive understanding of the global energy landscape and what challenges lay ahead in decarbonizing the global economy. I also learned how to analyze NDCs from a quantitative perspective.

I learned about fundamentals of hydropower, nuclear energy, petroleum engineering, coal, natural gas extraction, solar energy, and more emerging green energy technology. I learned about G20 and policies related to energy at an international level. learned about energy markets and auctions and ESG investing.
Very interesting, kind instructor; interesting topics; flexible model
Learned about current issues and developing technologies in energy, fossil fuels, renewable energy, etc.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
I believe the course would be improved if we had more discussion throughout the entire class period, rather than a lengthy discussion at the beginning followed by less discussion throughout the rest of the class period. Additionally, I really disliked being in a room with no windows for class.

Other than that, I really enjoyed the class and would like to thank Professor Oristaglio for such an amazing semester!

Strengths: The diversity in assignments; live auction, electricity market bidding, final presentation, mid-term paper, and footprint and lifecycle assesment. Instructor was not only professional, but extremely knowledgeable on subject. Welcoming of all opinions on the topic creating friendly, academic atmosphere. 
Weaknesses: Classroom can be at better location with more eye-friendly lighting (not criticism of class itself).
Teaching format could be improved - it is pretty heavy on the listening and less discussion based
You get out what you put in

Strength: I (and everyone else in the class) really enjoyed the energy market simulation!

Weakness: I wish more of the classes had hands-on components like the simulation and discussions. As the course was taught, a lot of it was lecture and felt repetitive from previous Energy Study courses. As this is a higher-level course, most students in the class were upperclassman and had already taken similar courses in the program.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would recommend this class - and the energy studies program as a whole - to any Yale student. I love the energy studies program as it provides participants with a comprehensive view of world energy while also providing flexibility in the classes you must take in the program.

I would highly recommend this course to students learning about the challenges in rising demand for energy and need to balance environmental concerns with society's needs. I learned a lot of scientific and policy-related knowledge on world energy and questions confronting clean energy transitions.
Yes, especially if they're doing Energy Studies!
If youre in Energy Studies, this is a great smaller seminar to break away from all the lectures youre used to taking.

Yes! It's a very relaxed environment to facilitate engaging discussions about world energy, and we cover many interesting concepts. Each week has a small selection of readings that is completely manageable, and the only sizable assignments are a short midterm paper and final presentation. Very discussion and learning focused in a pretty stress-free environment.
